我覺得有。細細個都唔信有鬼，中學同班同學去camp，6個人一間房，我地間屋有兩間房，對面房系個miss，一早就訓著左，果晚成班女仔去男仔間房聽個導遊講佢遇到既鬼故，我地聽到零晨2點幾先翻翻去我地間屋，我同個朋友對住個門口訓，其他人訓著曬既時候，我聽到有敲門聲，系一直敲冇人講野果種 敲完門就敲訓系隔離果面牆，個阿sir果日仲講左個半夜敲門千期唔好開門既鬼故，好撚恐怖，半夜一直敲個門同牆，本身我以爲訓我隔離果個都訓著，但原來佢未訓，我細細聲問佢聽唔聽到敲門聲敲牆聲，佢話聽到，我心已經知嗱野 間屋鎖匙得miss有，所以冇可能系啲男仔玩野，我一直未訓，亦都冇聽到有人開大門既聲，果日我系逼自己快啲訓著，真系好恐怖，依一世都記得

The discovery of infrared radiation is ascribed to astronomer William Herschel, who published his results in 1800 before the Royal Society of London.[33] Herschel used a glass prism to refract light from the Sun and detected invisible rays that caused heating beyond the red part of the spectrum, through an increase in the temperature recorded with a thermometer. These ”calorific rays“ were later termed infrared

German physicist Johann Wilhelm Ritter discovered ultraviolet in an experiment similar to Hershel’s, using sunlight and a glass prism. Ritter noted that invisible rays near the violet edge of a solar spectrum dispersed by a triangular prism darkened silver chloride preparations more quickly than did the nearby violet light. Ritter‘s experiments were an early precursor to what would become photography. Ritter noted that the ultraviolet rays (which at first were called ”chemical rays“) were capable of causing chemical reactions.

The discovery of infrared radiation is ascribed to astronomer William Herschel, who published his results in 1800 before the Royal Society of London.[33] Herschel used a glass prism to refract light from the Sun and detected invisible rays that caused heating beyond the red part of the spectrum, through an increase in the temperature recorded with a thermometer. These ”calorific rays“ were later termed infrared

German physicist Johann Wilhelm Ritter discovered ultraviolet in an experiment similar to Hershel’s, using sunlight and a glass prism. Ritter noted that invisible rays near the violet edge of a solar spectrum dispersed by a triangular prism darkened silver chloride preparations more quickly than did the nearby violet light. Ritter‘s experiments were an early precursor to what would become photography. Ritter noted that the ultraviolet rays (which at first were called ”chemical rays“) were capable of causing chemical reactions.
